article.headline: Teslaâs so-called Battery Day was âlong on vision and boldness,â short on here-and-now
article.body: A âsell the newsâ reaction was in full display Wednesday as Tesla Inc. shares sunk more than 8%, a day after the Silicon Valley car makerâs long-awaited âBattery Dayâ appeared to disappoint most on the Street. Teslaâs stock TSLA, +1.89% Â tumbled 8.6% in midday trading, and was on track for its lowest close in two weeks. Shares are down more than 20% in September, but have nearly quadrupled this year, compared with gains of less than 2% for the S&P 500 index SPX, +0.87%. Tesla late Tuesday unveiled a road map to what it called better, 56% cheaper and more efficient batteries set to lower electric-car prices. The plans included changes in battery size, design and engineering, and are being developed at a pilot battery plant in Fremont, Calif. The company also announced a future $25,000, fully autonomous car within three years and a longer-range, souped up âPlaidâ Model S sedan version. Read more about Teslaâs announcement. It was âclose to working,â Chief Executive Elon Musk said at the event. âIt does work but not with a high yield,â he went on to say, sending the stock plunging in the late session Tuesday. Wall Street latched onto that multiyear horizon and a perceived lack of specifics, although at least one investment bank upgraded its rating on to buy and recommended a âbuy the dip.â âOverall, Teslaâs battery day was long on vision and boldness, but short on specifics and near term deliverables,â Toni Sacconaghi with Bernstein said in a note Wednesday. The event âat times felt more visionary (even âvaporware-ishâ) than specific, with few detailsâ around production locations, timing, and key technical milestones achieved so far, he said. Moreover, an improved battery technology âwill only get Tesla a small part of the way towards achievingâ the goal of selling a $25,000 car, Sacconaghi said. On the positive side, Muskâs statement that he expected Tesla to grow 30% to 40% this year is consistent with earlier plans and âappears to imply a strong Q4,â he said. Emmanuel Rosner at Deutsche Bank upgraded Tesla stock to buy from hold, saying that Battery Day showcased an âimpressive trajectory for its technology, capacity and cost, which should help accelerate the worldâs shift to electric vehicles and extend Teslaâs lead considerably.â In addition to the planned battery-technology improvements and the âModel 2â $25,000 car, Tesla also unveiled plans to build âmassiveâ battery-cell capacity, which would open new markets for Tesla in long-haul trucking, stationary energy storage, and supplying batteries to other manufacturers, Rosner said. He raised his price target on Tesla to $500 from $400, implying a 26% upside from Wednesdayâs prices. âWith the stock price indicated down post market as traders âsell the news,â we recommend longer-term investors take advantage of weakness to buy Tesla as the best way to invest in vehicle electrification,â he said. Adam Jonas of Morgan Stanley highlighted the costs associated with Teslaâs battery plans. Battery Day âlargely lived up to the hype, but didnât clearly exceed it,â he said in a note. Teslaâs battery technology âis outpacing current growth in supply... and itâs time to spend significantly.â It is âtoo soon to tell if the increase in execution risk is commensurate with the potential increase in rewards beyond that already heavily discounted in the current share price,â Jonas said. Patrick Hummel at UBS said that âpatience was required,â since most of what Tesla presented on Battery Day is at least one year from fruition and lacked detail. âNonetheless, we remain confident Tesla remains the battery tech and cost leader,â he said, with the caveat that leadership âseems already fully discounted.â Garrett Nelson at CFRA said he came away âimpressedâ with Tesla plans, but the hype leading up to the event was such that the âsell the news reaction was perhaps unavoidable.â âIf there was any disappointment, we think it was the fact there was no mention of a million mile battery per se,â he said. Muskâs focus on lowering vehicle prices and making electric cars more affordable also may have raised some concerns among investors hoping that the companyâs innovations would instead result in âmust haveâ features, Nelson said. âNonetheless, we remain hard-pressed to find a more compelling EPS growth story and view [Teslaâs] addition to the S&P 500 as an eventuality and positive catalyst,â he said.
